div.p: 1. The manifestly dominant general word is gāo 高 (ant. bēi 卑 "low" and xià 下 "low") which refers to concrete as well as abstract elevation.
2. Shàng 上 (ant. xià 下 "lower") refers to the relatively high position of something, both abstractly and concretely.
3. Chóng 崇 (ant. bēi 卑 "lowly") and lóng 隆 (ant. wū 污 ) adds the notion of impressiveness to that of high elevation.
4. Qiáo 喬 refers specifically to the imposing tallness of trees.
5. Jùn 峻, wéi 巍, yán 巖, é 峨 are among the large number of poetic words referring to the imposing height of mountains.
6. Wēi 危 adds to the notion of the imposing (almost threatening) hight of something that of steepness of the slope, and the difficulty of access.
7. Lóng 隆 refers to imposing and impressive height, typically - but not always - of something artificial.
高級 is always figurative referring to a high level.
rough draft to BEGIN TO identify synonym group members for analysis, based on CL etc. 18.11.2003. CH ／

bibl.title: A Dictionary of Selected Synonyms in the Principal Indo-European Languages

note.p: 14. Inter Altum et excelsum, sublime et arduum. Altum ex superiori parte et inferiori est, excelsum ex superiori tantum; sublime excelsum est cum aliqua dignitate; arduum, excelsum est 4 cum aliqua [col. 12A] difficultate. Item altus puteus, murus excelsus. Summa videbis in excelso, ima in alto.
altus refers to height or depth as opposed to breadth
editurs "elevated" refers to high elevation as opposed to levelledness.
procerus "tall" refers to height or length as a result of growth.
arduus refers to height as associated with steepness and difficulty of access.
altitudo refers abstractly to height as such.
editum "something high" refers to height as associated with bulk"
proceritas "abundant height" refers to natural height associated with natural bulk and luxurious growth.

bibl.title: “荀子”單音節形容詞同義關係研究
Tolkovo-kombinatornyj slovar' sovremmenogo russkogo jazyka. Explanatory Combinatorial Dictionary of Modern Russian
Etymological Dictionary of Latin and the Other Italic Languages

entry.def: Shàng 上(ant. xià 下 "lower") refers to the relatively high position of something, both abstractly and concretely.

sense.def: up to the highest level, to its utmost
belonging to a superior or higher sphere of reality; belonging to a higher moral sphere; supreme, uttermost
operating on a higher metaphysical or moral level

entry.def: Wēi 危adds to the notion of the imposing (almost threatening) hight of something that of steepness of the slope, and the difficulty of access.

sense.def: precariously high, high and precipitous, liable to collapse, or liable to cause people to fall down (of mountains)
be precariously high, high and precipitous, liable to collapse, or liable to cause people to fall down (of mountains)

entry.def: Qiáo 喬refers specifically to the imposing tallness of trees.

sense.def: be high and impressive (primarily of trees)
be high and imposing 益尊
CC: lofty (as a hat); precipitous and high

entry.def: Jùn 峻, wéi 巍, yán 巖, é 峨 are among the large number of poetic words referring to the imposing height of mountains.
Jùn 峻, wéi 巍, yán 巖, é 峨 are among the large number of poetic words referring to the imposing height of mountains.

sense.def: high, outstanding and dangerous (as of mountains)
be high, outstanding and dangerous (as of mountains)

bibl.title: 簡明古漢語同義詞詞典

entry.def: Chóng 崇 (ant. bēi 卑 "lowly") and lóng 隆 (ant. wū 污) adds the notion of impressiveness to that of high elevation.

sense.def: high and impressive, imposing (of mountains or buildings)
be very high, be imposinly high: Yang Xiong, 甘泉賦
be high and impressive, imposing (of mountains or buildings); [be higher than][CA]

entry.def: Jùn 峻, wéi 巍, yán 巖, é 峨 are among the large number of poetic words referring to the imposing height of mountains.
Jùn 峻, wéi 巍, yán 巖, é 峨 are among the large number of poetic words referring to the imposing height of mountains.

sense.def: stand (above something or somebody); protrude (among something or somebody)

entry.def: Lóng 隆 refers to imposing and impressive height, typically - but not always - of something artificial.

sense.def: precariously high and inaccessible terrain, or mountains
rare, archaic, poetic: (of a person) tall and handsome
high (of the head; mostly in connection with 胡人)

entry.def: The manifestly dominant general word is gāo 高(ant. bēi 卑 "low" and xià 下 "low") which refers to concrete as well as abstract elevation.

sense.def: that which is high; the high thing; high point, elevation
reach the height of (so-and-so many 仞)
be elevated; be of a high degree; be on a high abstract level
make higher, cause to become higher, heighten
relative status, relative elevatedness; the dimension of being high or lowly
elevation of character, moral elevation; moral distinction
